item.title: Report I-2024050014
item.description:
Report I-2024050014

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-16T15:11:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-28
  • City: Atlanta
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PVS TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: PVS Transportation driver was scheduled to deliver a shipment of Sodium Bi Sulfite to City of Atlanta. Once the driver arrived on site he proceeded to the unloading location and met with the onsite representative. The onsite representative directed the driver to hook up to tank#1 connection. The driver hooked up to the unloading connection and proceeded to make the delivery. During the delivery the driver the driver was standing outside near his trailer connection and noticed a sound that didn' t represent offload and went to investigate. Upon investigation the driver noticed the unloading line wasn' t connected to the tank and the driver proceeded back to his truck to shut off the product flow. Approximately 300 gallons of Sodium Bisulfite was released into containment.

item.title: Report E-2024050178
item.description:
Report E-2024050178

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-13T15:12:55+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-24
  • City: CONLEY
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ROADRUNNER TRANSPORTATION SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On April 24, 2024, at 0858 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Roadrunner personnel in Conley, Georgia regarding the release of a total of 2 gallons of Muriatic Acid (UN1789, 8, II) from (15) 1-gallon poly jugs. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release was caused by the cargo being improperly loaded and was contained to a small area of the trailer floor, a 15ft x 3ft area of the concrete dock, multiple areas of asphalt and it also impacted a tire. Contractors were able to neutralize the release then clean the release with absorbents, and the proper PPE. All waste generated was placed in (3) 55-gallon DF’s and was staged onsite by contractors for proper disposal.
